## [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#postcard)Postcard
[![Documentation](https://docs.rs/postcard/badge.svg)](https://docs.rs/postcard)
Postcard is a `#![no_std]` focused serializer and deserializer for Serde.
Postcard aims to be convenient for developers in constrained environments, while allowing for flexibility to customize behavior as needed.
### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#design-goals)Design Goals
  1. Design primarily for `#![no_std]` usage, in embedded or other constrained contexts
  2. Support a maximal set of `serde` features, so `postcard` can be used as a drop in replacement
  3. Avoid special differences in code between communication code written for a microcontroller or a desktop/server PC
  4. Be resource efficient - memory usage, code size, developer time, and CPU time; in that order
  5. Allow library users to customize the serialization and deserialization behavior to fit their bespoke needs


### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#format-stability)Format Stability
As of v1.0.0, `postcard` has a documented and stable wire format. More information about this wire format can be found in the `spec/` folder of the Postcard repository, or viewed online at <https://postcard.jamesmunns.com>.
Work towards the Postcard Specification and portions of the Postcard 1.0 Release were sponsored by Mozilla Corporation.
### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#variable-length-data)Variable Length Data
All signed and unsigned integers larger than eight bits are encoded using a [Varint](https://postcard.jamesmunns.com/wire-format.html#varint-encoded-integers). This includes the length of array slices, as well as the discriminant of `enums`.
For more information, see the [Varint](https://postcard.jamesmunns.com/wire-format.html#varint-encoded-integers) chapter of the wire specification.
### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#example---serializationdeserialization)Example - Serialization/Deserialization
Postcard can serialize and deserialize messages similar to other `serde` formats.
Using the default `heapless` feature to serialize to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`:
```
use core::ops::Deref;
use serde::{Serialize, Deserialize};
use postcard::{from_bytes, to_vec};
use heapless::Vec;
#[derive(Serialize, Deserialize, Debug, Eq, PartialEq)]
struct RefStruct<'a> {
  bytes: &'a [u8],
  str_s: &'a str,
}
let message = "hElLo";
let bytes = [0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20];
let output: Vec<u8, 11> = to_vec(&RefStruct {
  bytes: &bytes,
  str_s: message,
}).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  &[0x04, 0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20, 0x05, b'h', b'E', b'l', b'L', b'o',],
  output.deref()
);
let out: RefStruct = from_bytes(output.deref()).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  out,
  RefStruct {
    bytes: &bytes,
    str_s: message,
  }
);
```

Or the optional `alloc` feature to serialize to an `alloc::vec::Vec<u8>`:
```
use core::ops::Deref;
use serde::{Serialize, Deserialize};
use postcard::{from_bytes, to_allocvec};
extern crate alloc;
use alloc::vec::Vec;
#[derive(Serialize, Deserialize, Debug, Eq, PartialEq)]
struct RefStruct<'a> {
  bytes: &'a [u8],
  str_s: &'a str,
}
let message = "hElLo";
let bytes = [0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20];
let output: Vec<u8> = to_allocvec(&RefStruct {
  bytes: &bytes,
  str_s: message,
}).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  &[0x04, 0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20, 0x05, b'h', b'E', b'l', b'L', b'o',],
  output.deref()
);
let out: RefStruct = from_bytes(output.deref()).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  out,
  RefStruct {
    bytes: &bytes,
    str_s: message,
  }
);
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#flavors)Flavors
`postcard` supports a system called `Flavors`, which are used to modify the way postcard serializes or processes serialized data. These flavors act as “plugins” or “middlewares” during the serialization or deserialization process, and can be combined to obtain complex protocol formats.
See the documentation of the `ser_flavors` or `de_flavors` modules for more information on usage.
### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#setup---cargotoml)Setup - `Cargo.toml`
Don’t forget to add [the `no-std` subset](https://serde.rs/no-std.html) of `serde` along with `postcard` to the `[dependencies]` section of your `Cargo.toml`!
```
[dependencies]
postcard = "1.0.0"
# By default, `serde` has the `std` feature enabled, which makes it unsuitable for embedded targets
# disabling default-features fixes this
serde = { version = "1.0.*", default-features = false }
```

at your option.

Unless you explicitly state otherwise, any contribution intentionally submitted for inclusion in the work by you, as defined in the Apache-2.0 license, shall be dual licensed as above, without any additional terms or conditions.

    Experimental Postcard Features

    Fixed Size Integers

    Serialization Flavors
## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#structs)

[Deserializer](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/struct.Deserializer.html "struct postcard::Deserializer")
    A `serde` compatible deserializer, generic over “Flavors” of deserializing plugins.

    A `serde` compatible serializer, generic over “Flavors” of serializing plugins.
## Enums[§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#enums)

[Error](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/enum.Error.html "enum postcard::Error")
    This is the error type used by Postcard
## Functions[§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#functions)

[from_bytes](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.from_bytes.html "fn postcard::from_bytes")
    Deserialize a message of type `T` from a byte slice. The unused portion (if any) of the byte slice is not returned.

[from_bytes_cobs](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.from_bytes_cobs.html "fn postcard::from_bytes_cobs")
    Deserialize a message of type `T` from a cobs-encoded byte slice.

[from_bytes_crc32](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.from_bytes_crc32.html "fn postcard::from_bytes_crc32")
    Conveniently deserialize a message of type `T` from a byte slice with a Crc. The unused portion (if any) of the byte slice is not returned.

[from_eio](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.from_eio.html "fn postcard::from_eio")
    Deserialize a message of type `T` from a [`embedded_io`](https://docs.rs/embedded-io/0.6.1/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/embedded_io/index.html "mod embedded_io")::[`Read`](https://docs.rs/embedded-io/0.6.1/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/embedded_io/trait.Read.html "trait embedded_io::Read").

[from_io](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.from_io.html "fn postcard::from_io")
    Deserialize a message of type `T` from a [`std::io::Read`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/io/trait.Read.html "trait std::io::Read").

[serialize_with_flavor](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.serialize_with_flavor.html "fn postcard::serialize_with_flavor")
    `serialize_with_flavor()` has three generic parameters, `T, F, O`.

[take_from_bytes](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.take_from_bytes.html "fn postcard::take_from_bytes")
    Deserialize a message of type `T` from a byte slice. The unused portion (if any) of the byte slice is returned for further usage

[take_from_bytes_cobs](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.take_from_bytes_cobs.html "fn postcard::take_from_bytes_cobs")
    Deserialize a message of type `T` from a cobs-encoded byte slice.

[take_from_bytes_crc32](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.take_from_bytes_crc32.html "fn postcard::take_from_bytes_crc32")
    Conveniently deserialize a message of type `T` from a byte slice with a Crc. The unused portion (if any) of the byte slice is returned for further usage

[to_allocvec](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_allocvec.html "fn postcard::to_allocvec")
    Serialize a `T` to an `alloc::vec::Vec<u8>`.

[to_allocvec_cobs](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_allocvec_cobs.html "fn postcard::to_allocvec_cobs")
    Serialize and COBS encode a `T` to an `alloc::vec::Vec<u8>`.

[to_allocvec_crc32](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_allocvec_crc32.html "fn postcard::to_allocvec_crc32")
    Conveniently serialize a `T` to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`, with the `Vec` containing data followed by a 32-bit CRC. The CRC bytes are included in the output `Vec`.

[to_eio](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_eio.html "fn postcard::to_eio")
    Serialize a `T` to an [`embedded_io Write`](https://docs.rs/embedded-io/0.6.1/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/embedded_io/trait.Write.html "trait embedded_io::Write"),

[to_extend](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_extend.html "fn postcard::to_extend")
    Serialize a `T` to a [`core::iter::Extend`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/core/iter/traits/collect/trait.Extend.html "trait core::iter::traits::collect::Extend"),

[to_io](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_io.html "fn postcard::to_io")
    Serialize a `T` to a [`std::io::Write`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/io/trait.Write.html "trait std::io::Write"),

[to_slice](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_slice.html "fn postcard::to_slice")
    Serialize a `T` to the given slice, with the resulting slice containing data in a serialized format.

[to_slice_cobs](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_slice_cobs.html "fn postcard::to_slice_cobs")
    Serialize a `T` to the given slice, with the resulting slice containing data in a serialized then COBS encoded format. The terminating sentinel `0x00` byte is included in the output buffer.

[to_slice_crc32](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_slice_crc32.html "fn postcard::to_slice_crc32")
    Conveniently serialize a `T` to the given slice, with the resulting slice containing data followed by a 32-bit CRC. The CRC bytes are included in the output buffer.

[to_stdvec](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_stdvec.html "fn postcard::to_stdvec")
    Serialize a `T` to a `std::vec::Vec<u8>`.

[to_stdvec_cobs](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_stdvec_cobs.html "fn postcard::to_stdvec_cobs")
    Serialize and COBS encode a `T` to a `std::vec::Vec<u8>`.

[to_stdvec_crc32](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_stdvec_crc32.html "fn postcard::to_stdvec_crc32")
    Conveniently serialize a `T` to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`, with the `Vec` containing data followed by a 32-bit CRC. The CRC bytes are included in the output `Vec`.

[to_vec](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_vec.html "fn postcard::to_vec")
    Serialize a `T` to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`, with the `Vec` containing data in a serialized format.

[to_vec_cobs](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_vec_cobs.html "fn postcard::to_vec_cobs")
    Serialize a `T` to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`, with the `Vec` containing data in a serialized then COBS encoded format. The terminating sentinel `0x00` byte is included in the output `Vec`.

[to_vec_crc32](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_vec_crc32.html "fn postcard::to_vec_crc32")
    Conveniently serialize a `T` to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`, with the `Vec` containing data followed by a 32-bit CRC. The CRC bytes are included in the output `Vec`.

    This is the Result type used by Postcard.

# Postcard
[![Documentation](https://img.gs/czjpqfbdkz/full/https://docs.rs/postcard/badge.svg)](https://docs.rs/postcard)
Postcard is a ````#!``[``no_std``]```` focused serializer and deserializer for Serde.
Postcard aims to be convenient for developers in constrained environments, while allowing for flexibility to customize behavior as needed.
## Design Goals
  1. Design primarily for ````#!``[``no_std``]```` usage, in embedded or other constrained contexts
  2. Support a maximal set of ``serde`` features, so ``postcard`` can be used as a drop in replacement
  3. Avoid special differences in code between communication code written for a microcontroller or a desktop/server PC
  4. Be resource efficient - memory usage, code size, developer time, and CPU time; in that order
  5. Allow library users to customize the serialization and deserialization behavior to fit their bespoke needs


## Format Stability
As of v1.0.0, ``postcard`` has a documented and stable wire format. More information about this wire format can be found in the ``spec/`` folder of the Postcard repository, or viewed online at <https://postcard.jamesmunns.com>.
Work towards the Postcard Specification and portions of the Postcard 1.0 Release were sponsored by Mozilla Corporation.
## Variable Length Data
All signed and unsigned integers larger than eight bits are encoded using a [Varint](https://postcard.jamesmunns.com/wire-format.html#varint-encoded-integers). This includes the length of array slices, as well as the discriminant of ``enums``.
For more information, see the [Varint](https://postcard.jamesmunns.com/wire-format.html#varint-encoded-integers) chapter of the wire specification.
## Example - Serialization/Deserialization
Postcard can serialize and deserialize messages similar to other ``serde`` formats.
Using the default ``heapless`` feature to serialize to a ```heapless`::``Vec``<``u8``>````:
```
``use` `core`::```ops`::``Deref`;`
`use` `serde`::````{`Serialize`,` Deserialize```}```;`
`use` `postcard`::````{`from_bytes`,` to_vec```}```;`
`use` `heapless`::``Vec`;`
``#``[``derive```(```Serialize`,` Deserialize`,` Debug`,` Eq`,` PartialEq```)```]``
``struct` ````RefStruct``<``'a``>``````{`
  `bytes``:` `&``'a` [`u8`],
  `str_s``:` `&``'a` `str`,
```}```
`let` message `=` ``"`hElLo`"```;`
`let` bytes `=` `[``0x01``,` `0x10``,` `0x02``,` `0x20``]``;`
`let` output`:` ``Vec``<``u8`, 11`>`` `=` `to_vec``(``&`RefStruct ``{`
  bytes`:` `&`bytes`,`
  str_s`:` message`,`
```}```)``.``unwrap``(``)``;`
`assert_eq!``(`
  `&``[``0x04``,` `0x01``,` `0x10``,` `0x02``,` `0x20``,` `0x05``,` ``b``'`h`'```,` ``b``'`E`'```,` ``b``'`l`'```,` ``b``'`L`'```,` ``b``'`o`'```,``]``,`
  output`.``deref``(``)`
`)``;`
`let` out`:` RefStruct `=` `from_bytes``(`output`.``deref``(``)``)``.``unwrap``(``)``;`
`assert_eq!``(`
  out`,`
  RefStruct ``{`
    bytes`:` `&`bytes`,`
    str_s`:` message`,`
  ```}``
`)``;`
`
```

Or the optional ``alloc`` feature to serialize to an ```alloc`::```vec`::``Vec``<``u8``>````:
```
``use` `core`::```ops`::``Deref`;`
`use` `serde`::````{`Serialize`,` Deserialize```}```;`
`use` `postcard`::````{`from_bytes`,` to_allocvec```}```;`
`extern` `crate` alloc`;`
`use` `alloc`::```vec`::``Vec`;`
``#``[``derive```(```Serialize`,` Deserialize`,` Debug`,` Eq`,` PartialEq```)```]``
``struct` ````RefStruct``<``'a``>``````{`
  `bytes``:` `&``'a` [`u8`],
  `str_s``:` `&``'a` `str`,
```}```
`let` message `=` ``"`hElLo`"```;`
`let` bytes `=` `[``0x01``,` `0x10``,` `0x02``,` `0x20``]``;`
`let` output`:` ``Vec``<``u8``>`` `=` `to_allocvec``(``&`RefStruct ``{`
  bytes`:` `&`bytes`,`
  str_s`:` message`,`
```}```)``.``unwrap``(``)``;`
`assert_eq!``(`
  `&``[``0x04``,` `0x01``,` `0x10``,` `0x02``,` `0x20``,` `0x05``,` ``b``'`h`'```,` ``b``'`E`'```,` ``b``'`l`'```,` ``b``'`L`'```,` ``b``'`o`'```,``]``,`
  output`.``deref``(``)`
`)``;`
`let` out`:` RefStruct `=` `from_bytes``(`output`.``deref``(``)``)``.``unwrap``(``)``;`
`assert_eq!``(`
  out`,`
  RefStruct ``{`
    bytes`:` `&`bytes`,`
    str_s`:` message`,`
  ```}``
`)``;`
`
```

## Flavors
``postcard`` supports a system called ``Flavors``, which are used to modify the way postcard serializes or processes serialized data. These flavors act as "plugins" or "middlewares" during the serialization or deserialization process, and can be combined to obtain complex protocol formats.
See the documentation of the ``ser_flavors`` or ``de_flavors`` modules for more information on usage.
## Setup - ``Cargo.toml``
Don't forget to add [the ``no-std`` subset](https://serde.rs/no-std.html) of ``serde`` along with ``postcard`` to the ````[``dependencies``]```` section of your ``Cargo.toml``!
```
```[``dependencies``]`
`postcard ``=` ``"`1.0.0`"``
``# By default, `serde` has the `std` feature enabled, which makes it unsuitable for embedded targets``
``# disabling default-features fixes this``
`serde = { version = "1.0.*", default-features ``=` `false` }
``
```

`)``;`

## Flavors
``postcard`` supports a system called ``Flavors``, which are used to modify the way postcard serializes or processes serialized data. These flavors act as "plugins" or "middlewares" during the serialization or deserialization process, and can be combined to obtain complex protocol formats.

## [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#postcard)Postcard
[![Documentation](https://docs.rs/postcard/badge.svg)](https://docs.rs/postcard)
Postcard is a `#![no_std]` focused serializer and deserializer for Serde.
Postcard aims to be convenient for developers in constrained environments, while allowing for flexibility to customize behavior as needed.
### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#design-goals)Design Goals
  1. Design primarily for `#![no_std]` usage, in embedded or other constrained contexts
  2. Support a maximal set of `serde` features, so `postcard` can be used as a drop in replacement
  3. Avoid special differences in code between communication code written for a microcontroller or a desktop/server PC
  4. Be resource efficient - memory usage, code size, developer time, and CPU time; in that order
  5. Allow library users to customize the serialization and deserialization behavior to fit their bespoke needs


### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#format-stability)Format Stability
As of v1.0.0, `postcard` has a documented and stable wire format. More information about this wire format can be found in the `spec/` folder of the Postcard repository, or viewed online at <https://postcard.jamesmunns.com>.
Work towards the Postcard Specification and portions of the Postcard 1.0 Release were sponsored by Mozilla Corporation.
### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#variable-length-data)Variable Length Data
All signed and unsigned integers larger than eight bits are encoded using a [Varint](https://postcard.jamesmunns.com/wire-format.html#varint-encoded-integers). This includes the length of array slices, as well as the discriminant of `enums`.
For more information, see the [Varint](https://postcard.jamesmunns.com/wire-format.html#varint-encoded-integers) chapter of the wire specification.
### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#example---serializationdeserialization)Example - Serialization/Deserialization
Postcard can serialize and deserialize messages similar to other `serde` formats.
Using the default `heapless` feature to serialize to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`:
```
use core::ops::Deref;
use serde::{Serialize, Deserialize};
use postcard::{from_bytes, to_vec};
use heapless::Vec;
#[derive(Serialize, Deserialize, Debug, Eq, PartialEq)]
struct RefStruct<'a> {
  bytes: &'a [u8],
  str_s: &'a str,
}
let message = "hElLo";
let bytes = [0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20];
let output: Vec<u8, 11> = to_vec(&RefStruct {
  bytes: &bytes,
  str_s: message,
}).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  &[0x04, 0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20, 0x05, b'h', b'E', b'l', b'L', b'o',],
  output.deref()
);
let out: RefStruct = from_bytes(output.deref()).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  out,
  RefStruct {
    bytes: &bytes,
    str_s: message,
  }
);
```

Or the optional `alloc` feature to serialize to an `alloc::vec::Vec<u8>`:
```
use core::ops::Deref;
use serde::{Serialize, Deserialize};
use postcard::{from_bytes, to_allocvec};
extern crate alloc;
use alloc::vec::Vec;
#[derive(Serialize, Deserialize, Debug, Eq, PartialEq)]
struct RefStruct<'a> {
  bytes: &'a [u8],
  str_s: &'a str,
}
let message = "hElLo";
let bytes = [0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20];
let output: Vec<u8> = to_allocvec(&RefStruct {
  bytes: &bytes,
  str_s: message,
}).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  &[0x04, 0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20, 0x05, b'h', b'E', b'l', b'L', b'o',],
  output.deref()
);
let out: RefStruct = from_bytes(output.deref()).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  out,
  RefStruct {
    bytes: &bytes,
    str_s: message,
  }
);
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#flavors)Flavors
`postcard` supports a system called `Flavors`, which are used to modify the way postcard serializes or processes serialized data. These flavors act as “plugins” or “middlewares” during the serialization or deserialization process, and can be combined to obtain complex protocol formats.
See the documentation of the `ser_flavors` or `de_flavors` modules for more information on usage.
### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#setup---cargotoml)Setup - `Cargo.toml`
Don’t forget to add [the `no-std` subset](https://serde.rs/no-std.html) of `serde` along with `postcard` to the `[dependencies]` section of your `Cargo.toml`!
```
[dependencies]
postcard = "1.0.0"
# By default, `serde` has the `std` feature enabled, which makes it unsuitable for embedded targets
# disabling default-features fixes this
serde = { version = "1.0.*", default-features = false }
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#license)License
Licensed under either of
  * Apache License, Version 2.0 ([LICENSE-APACHE](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/LICENSE-APACHE) or <http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0>)
  * MIT license ([LICENSE-MIT](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/LICENSE-MIT) or <http://opensource.org/licenses/MIT>)


at your option.
#### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#contribution)Contribution
Unless you explicitly state otherwise, any contribution intentionally submitted for inclusion in the work by you, as defined in the Apache-2.0 license, shall be dual licensed as above, without any additional terms or conditions.
## Modules[§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#modules)

[accumulator](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/accumulator/index.html "mod postcard::accumulator")
    An accumulator used to collect chunked COBS data and deserialize it.

[de_flavors](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/de_flavors/index.html "mod postcard::de_flavors")
    Deserialization Flavors

[experimental](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/experimental/index.html "mod postcard::experimental")
    Experimental Postcard Features

[fixint](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fixint/index.html "mod postcard::fixint")
    Fixed Size Integers

[ser_flavors](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/ser_flavors/index.html "mod postcard::ser_flavors")
    Serialization Flavors
## Structs[§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#structs)

[Deserializer](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/struct.Deserializer.html "struct postcard::Deserializer")
    A `serde` compatible deserializer, generic over “Flavors” of deserializing plugins.

[Serializer](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/struct.Serializer.html "struct postcard::Serializer")
    A `serde` compatible serializer, generic over “Flavors” of serializing plugins.
## Enums[§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#enums)

[Error](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/enum.Error.html "enum postcard::Error")
    This is the error type used by Postcard
## Functions[§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#functions)

[from_bytes](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.from_bytes.html "fn postcard::from_bytes")
    Deserialize a message of type `T` from a byte slice. The unused portion (if any) of the byte slice is not returned.

[from_bytes_cobs](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.from_bytes_cobs.html "fn postcard::from_bytes_cobs")
    Deserialize a message of type `T` from a cobs-encoded byte slice.

[from_bytes_crc32](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.from_bytes_crc32.html "fn postcard::from_bytes_crc32")
    Conveniently deserialize a message of type `T` from a byte slice with a Crc. The unused portion (if any) of the byte slice is not returned.

[from_eio](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.from_eio.html "fn postcard::from_eio")
    Deserialize a message of type `T` from a [`embedded_io`](https://docs.rs/embedded-io/0.6.1/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/embedded_io/index.html "mod embedded_io")::[`Read`](https://docs.rs/embedded-io/0.6.1/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/embedded_io/trait.Read.html "trait embedded_io::Read").

[from_io](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.from_io.html "fn postcard::from_io")
    Deserialize a message of type `T` from a [`std::io::Read`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/io/trait.Read.html "trait std::io::Read").

[serialize_with_flavor](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.serialize_with_flavor.html "fn postcard::serialize_with_flavor")
    `serialize_with_flavor()` has three generic parameters, `T, F, O`.

[take_from_bytes](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.take_from_bytes.html "fn postcard::take_from_bytes")
    Deserialize a message of type `T` from a byte slice. The unused portion (if any) of the byte slice is returned for further usage

[take_from_bytes_cobs](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.take_from_bytes_cobs.html "fn postcard::take_from_bytes_cobs")
    Deserialize a message of type `T` from a cobs-encoded byte slice.

[take_from_bytes_crc32](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.take_from_bytes_crc32.html "fn postcard::take_from_bytes_crc32")
    Conveniently deserialize a message of type `T` from a byte slice with a Crc. The unused portion (if any) of the byte slice is returned for further usage

[to_allocvec](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_allocvec.html "fn postcard::to_allocvec")
    Serialize a `T` to an `alloc::vec::Vec<u8>`.

[to_allocvec_cobs](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_allocvec_cobs.html "fn postcard::to_allocvec_cobs")
    Serialize and COBS encode a `T` to an `alloc::vec::Vec<u8>`.

[to_allocvec_crc32](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_allocvec_crc32.html "fn postcard::to_allocvec_crc32")
    Conveniently serialize a `T` to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`, with the `Vec` containing data followed by a 32-bit CRC. The CRC bytes are included in the output `Vec`.

[to_eio](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_eio.html "fn postcard::to_eio")
    Serialize a `T` to an [`embedded_io Write`](https://docs.rs/embedded-io/0.6.1/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/embedded_io/trait.Write.html "trait embedded_io::Write"),

[to_extend](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_extend.html "fn postcard::to_extend")
    Serialize a `T` to a [`core::iter::Extend`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/core/iter/traits/collect/trait.Extend.html "trait core::iter::traits::collect::Extend"),

[to_io](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_io.html "fn postcard::to_io")
    Serialize a `T` to a [`std::io::Write`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/nightly/std/io/trait.Write.html "trait std::io::Write"),

[to_slice](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_slice.html "fn postcard::to_slice")
    Serialize a `T` to the given slice, with the resulting slice containing data in a serialized format.

[to_slice_cobs](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_slice_cobs.html "fn postcard::to_slice_cobs")
    Serialize a `T` to the given slice, with the resulting slice containing data in a serialized then COBS encoded format. The terminating sentinel `0x00` byte is included in the output buffer.

[to_slice_crc32](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_slice_crc32.html "fn postcard::to_slice_crc32")
    Conveniently serialize a `T` to the given slice, with the resulting slice containing data followed by a 32-bit CRC. The CRC bytes are included in the output buffer.

[to_stdvec](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_stdvec.html "fn postcard::to_stdvec")
    Serialize a `T` to a `std::vec::Vec<u8>`.

[to_stdvec_cobs](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_stdvec_cobs.html "fn postcard::to_stdvec_cobs")
    Serialize and COBS encode a `T` to a `std::vec::Vec<u8>`.

[to_stdvec_crc32](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_stdvec_crc32.html "fn postcard::to_stdvec_crc32")
    Conveniently serialize a `T` to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`, with the `Vec` containing data followed by a 32-bit CRC. The CRC bytes are included in the output `Vec`.

[to_vec](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_vec.html "fn postcard::to_vec")
    Serialize a `T` to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`, with the `Vec` containing data in a serialized format.

[to_vec_cobs](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_vec_cobs.html "fn postcard::to_vec_cobs")
    Serialize a `T` to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`, with the `Vec` containing data in a serialized then COBS encoded format. The terminating sentinel `0x00` byte is included in the output `Vec`.

[to_vec_crc32](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/fn.to_vec_crc32.html "fn postcard::to_vec_crc32")
    Conveniently serialize a `T` to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`, with the `Vec` containing data followed by a 32-bit CRC. The CRC bytes are included in the output `Vec`.

    This is the Result type used by Postcard.

### §⟨11⟩Flavors
`postcard` supports a system called `Flavors`, which are used to modify the way postcard serializes or processes serialized data. These flavors act as “plugins” or “middlewares” during the serialization or deserialization process, and can be combined to obtain complex protocol formats.
See the documentation of the `ser_flavors` or `de_flavors` modules for more information on usage.
### §⟨12⟩Setup - `Cargo.toml`
Don’t forget to add the `no-std` subset⟨13⟩ of `serde` along with `postcard` to the `[dependencies]` section of your `Cargo.toml`!
```
[dependencies]
postcard = "1.0.0"
# By default, `serde` has the `std` feature enabled, which makes it unsuitable for embedded targets
# disabling default-features fixes this
serde = { version = "1.0.*", default-features = false }
```

## [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#postcard)Postcard
[![Documentation](https://docs.rs/postcard/badge.svg)](https://docs.rs/postcard)
Postcard is a `#![no_std]` focused serializer and deserializer for Serde.
Postcard aims to be convenient for developers in constrained environments, while allowing for flexibility to customize behavior as needed.
### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#design-goals)Design Goals
  1. Design primarily for `#![no_std]` usage, in embedded or other constrained contexts
  2. Support a maximal set of `serde` features, so `postcard` can be used as a drop in replacement
  3. Avoid special differences in code between communication code written for a microcontroller or a desktop/server PC
  4. Be resource efficient - memory usage, code size, developer time, and CPU time; in that order
  5. Allow library users to customize the serialization and deserialization behavior to fit their bespoke needs


### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#format-stability)Format Stability
As of v1.0.0, `postcard` has a documented and stable wire format. More information about this wire format can be found in the `spec/` folder of the Postcard repository, or viewed online at <https://postcard.jamesmunns.com>.
Work towards the Postcard Specification and portions of the Postcard 1.0 Release were sponsored by Mozilla Corporation.
### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#variable-length-data)Variable Length Data
All signed and unsigned integers larger than eight bits are encoded using a [Varint](https://postcard.jamesmunns.com/wire-format.html#varint-encoded-integers). This includes the length of array slices, as well as the discriminant of `enums`.
For more information, see the [Varint](https://postcard.jamesmunns.com/wire-format.html#varint-encoded-integers) chapter of the wire specification.
### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#example---serializationdeserialization)Example - Serialization/Deserialization
Postcard can serialize and deserialize messages similar to other `serde` formats.
Using the default `heapless` feature to serialize to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`:
```
use core::ops::Deref;
use serde::{Serialize, Deserialize};
use postcard::{from_bytes, to_vec};
use heapless::Vec;
#[derive(Serialize, Deserialize, Debug, Eq, PartialEq)]
struct RefStruct<'a> {
  bytes: &'a [u8],
  str_s: &'a str,
}
let message = "hElLo";
let bytes = [0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20];
let output: Vec<u8, 11> = to_vec(&RefStruct {
  bytes: &bytes,
  str_s: message,
}).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  &[0x04, 0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20, 0x05, b'h', b'E', b'l', b'L', b'o',],
  output.deref()
);
let out: RefStruct = from_bytes(output.deref()).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  out,
  RefStruct {
    bytes: &bytes,
    str_s: message,
  }
);
```

Or the optional `alloc` feature to serialize to an `alloc::vec::Vec<u8>`:
```
use core::ops::Deref;
use serde::{Serialize, Deserialize};
use postcard::{from_bytes, to_allocvec};
extern crate alloc;
use alloc::vec::Vec;
#[derive(Serialize, Deserialize, Debug, Eq, PartialEq)]
struct RefStruct<'a> {
  bytes: &'a [u8],
  str_s: &'a str,
}
let message = "hElLo";
let bytes = [0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20];
let output: Vec<u8> = to_allocvec(&RefStruct {
  bytes: &bytes,
  str_s: message,
}).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  &[0x04, 0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20, 0x05, b'h', b'E', b'l', b'L', b'o',],
  output.deref()
);
let out: RefStruct = from_bytes(output.deref()).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  out,
  RefStruct {
    bytes: &bytes,
    str_s: message,
  }
);
```

### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#flavors)Flavors
`postcard` supports a system called `Flavors`, which are used to modify the way postcard serializes or processes serialized data. These flavors act as “plugins” or “middlewares” during the serialization or deserialization process, and can be combined to obtain complex protocol formats.
See the documentation of the `ser_flavors` or `de_flavors` modules for more information on usage.
### [§](https://docs.rs/postcard/latest/postcard/#setup---cargotoml)Setup - `Cargo.toml`
Don’t forget to add [the `no-std` subset](https://serde.rs/no-std.html) of `serde` along with `postcard` to the `[dependencies]` section of your `Cargo.toml`!
```
[dependencies]
postcard = "1.0.0"
# By default, `serde` has the `std` feature enabled, which makes it unsuitable for embedded targets
# disabling default-features fixes this
serde = { version = "1.0.*", default-features = false }
```

## §⟨4⟩Postcard
![Documentation⟨5⟩](https://docs.rs/postcard)
Postcard is a `#![no_std]` focused serializer and deserializer for Serde.
Postcard aims to be convenient for developers in constrained environments, while allowing for flexibility to customize behavior as needed.
### §⟨6⟩Design Goals
  1. Design primarily for `#![no_std]` usage, in embedded or other constrained contexts
  2. Support a maximal set of `serde` features, so `postcard` can be used as a drop in replacement
  3. Avoid special differences in code between communication code written for a microcontroller or a desktop/server PC
  4. Be resource efficient - memory usage, code size, developer time, and CPU time; in that order
  5. Allow library users to customize the serialization and deserialization behavior to fit their bespoke needs


### §⟨7⟩Format Stability
As of v1.0.0, `postcard` has a documented and stable wire format. More information about this wire format can be found in the `spec/` folder of the Postcard repository, or viewed online at <https://postcard.jamesmunns.com>.
Work towards the Postcard Specification and portions of the Postcard 1.0 Release were sponsored by Mozilla Corporation.
### §⟨8⟩Variable Length Data
All signed and unsigned integers larger than eight bits are encoded using a Varint⟨9⟩. This includes the length of array slices, as well as the discriminant of `enums`.
For more information, see the Varint⟨9⟩ chapter of the wire specification.
### §⟨10⟩Example - Serialization/Deserialization
Postcard can serialize and deserialize messages similar to other `serde` formats.
Using the default `heapless` feature to serialize to a `heapless::Vec<u8>`:
```
use core::ops::Deref;
use serde::{Serialize, Deserialize};
use postcard::{from_bytes, to_vec};
use heapless::Vec;
#[derive(Serialize, Deserialize, Debug, Eq, PartialEq)]
struct RefStruct<'a> {
  bytes: &'a [u8],
  str_s: &'a str,
}
let message = "hElLo";
let bytes = [0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20];
let output: Vec<u8, 11> = to_vec(&RefStruct {
  bytes: &bytes,
  str_s: message,
}).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  &[0x04, 0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20, 0x05, b'h', b'E', b'l', b'L', b'o',],
  output.deref()
);
let out: RefStruct = from_bytes(output.deref()).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  out,
  RefStruct {
    bytes: &bytes,
    str_s: message,
  }
);
```

Or the optional `alloc` feature to serialize to an `alloc::vec::Vec<u8>`:
```
use core::ops::Deref;
use serde::{Serialize, Deserialize};
use postcard::{from_bytes, to_allocvec};
extern crate alloc;
use alloc::vec::Vec;
#[derive(Serialize, Deserialize, Debug, Eq, PartialEq)]
struct RefStruct<'a> {
  bytes: &'a [u8],
  str_s: &'a str,
}
let message = "hElLo";
let bytes = [0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20];
let output: Vec<u8> = to_allocvec(&RefStruct {
  bytes: &bytes,
  str_s: message,
}).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  &[0x04, 0x01, 0x10, 0x02, 0x20, 0x05, b'h', b'E', b'l', b'L', b'o',],
  output.deref()
);
let out: RefStruct = from_bytes(output.deref()).unwrap();
assert_eq!(
  out,
  RefStruct {
    bytes: &bytes,
    str_s: message,
  }
);
```

### §⟨11⟩Flavors
`postcard` supports a system called `Flavors`, which are used to modify the way postcard serializes or processes serialized data. These flavors act as “plugins” or “middlewares” during the serialization or deserialization process, and can be combined to obtain complex protocol formats.
See the documentation of the `ser_flavors` or `de_flavors` modules for more information on usage.
### §⟨12⟩Setup - `Cargo.toml`
Don’t forget to add the `no-std` subset⟨13⟩ of `serde` along with `postcard` to the `[dependencies]` section of your `Cargo.toml`!
```
[dependencies]
postcard = "1.0.0"
# By default, `serde` has the `std` feature enabled, which makes it unsuitable for embedded targets
# disabling default-features fixes this
serde = { version = "1.0.*", default-features = false }
```

enriched_crate.readme_summary: The `postcard` crate is a `#![no_std]`-focused serializer and deserializer for `serde`, designed for embedded and constrained environments. It features a stable wire format, resource-efficient serialization using varint encoding for variable-length data, and customizable "Flavors" for flexible serialization/deserialization behavior. It supports both `heapless` and `alloc`-based serialization and is ideal for applications requiring minimal memory and CPU usage.
enriched_crate.factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Serialization and Deserialization  
✅ **Factual**: Postcard provides serialization and deserialization capabilities for `serde`-compatible data structures, making it suitable for constrained environments by default due to its `#![no_std]` design.  
❌ **Counterfactual**: Postcard requires the `std` feature to enable serialization and deserialization, making it incompatible with embedded systems or other constrained environments.  

---

### Pair 2: Wire Format Stability  
✅ **Factual**: As of version 1.0.0, Postcard has a documented and stable wire format, ensuring compatibility across versions and providing detailed specifications for developers.  
❌ **Counterfactual**: Postcard’s wire format changes frequently between versions, making it unsuitable for applications requiring long-term format stability.  

---

### Pair 3: Variable-Length Data Encoding  
✅ **Factual**: Postcard uses Varint encoding for integers larger than eight bits, including array slice lengths and enum discriminants, optimizing for space efficiency in serialized data.  
❌ **Counterfactual**: Postcard encodes all integers using fixed-width formats, which can lead to inefficient use of memory for small values in constrained environments.
